Identification_Information:
Citation:
Citation_Information:
Originator:
California Department of Fish and Game/Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission
Publication_Date: 02/19/03
Title: cdfg_100k_2003_1
Geospatial_Data_Presentation_Form: vector digital data
Online_Linkage: \\ISB-TCHRISTY\D$\route100k\huclist\cdfg_100k_2003_1.shp
Description:
Abstract:
This measured shapefile was derived from an Arc/Info coverage. It is an interim product (as described below in the Supplemental Information). The coverage utilizes existing National Hydrography Database (NHD) linework and attributes as well as Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) identifiers to determine the stream networks that are be combined into routes. A series of line segments from the NHD were networked into a stream first by the existence of a GNIS ID. If no GNIS ID was present for a series of segments, the NHD "Level" attribute was used to determine the network. Once a unique network ID was assigned to a series of line segments they were combined into a route by determining coordinates at the mouth of the stream and calculating distance upstream from the mouth.
Purpose:
The combination of established streams (GNIS) and calculated stream levels (relating flow with spatial attributes) creates a stream layer more complete and compatible with fisheries applications. Stream based hydrography expands the options available for storing location information by reducing the number of records needed to describe a location event. As a result, PSMFC/CDFG will benefit from the stream based hydrography in its efforts to maintain a large database of stream based data.
Supplemental_Information:
This is an interim product. It contains all streams in California that are currently considered to contain anadromous species, but a large number of linework issues continue to be examined by the data technician at the time of release. About 1,770 of the approx. 34,000 streams in this shapefile had been flagged for having no downstream LLID, e.g. they do not flow into another stream. Of these 1,770 about 800 have been examined and either repaired (linework added or downstream connection made with exisiting linework) or flagged with an explanation value in the "Mouth" attribute field. The remaining 970 streams will have been examined and either repaired or flagged prior to the release of the next version of this hydrography. At this time, it is planned that this second release (March 2003) will be the second of three versions, the third being the second version plus the remainder of the State of California (the complete 100k hydrography for California). Tentative release date of the final (third) version is Summer 2003.

2003120210334900FALSE20031202143118002003120214311800{123837EF-29C9-481A-928F-4B6EEB2232CE}Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.3.0.800enCdfg_100k_2003_6.shp is a 1:100,000 scale stream based routed hydrography covering the entire State of California. This measured shapefile was derived from an Arc/Info coverage. The coverage utilizes existing National Hydrography Database (NHD) 1:100,000 linework and attributes as well as Geographic Names Information System (GNIS) identifiers as guidelines to determine the stream networks that were referenced into routes. Utilizing both automatic routines developed by California Department of Fish and Game (CDFG) and Pacific States Marine Fisheries Commission (PSMFC) staff as well as manual (on screen) networking techniques, a series of arcs from the NHD were networked into a stream first by the existence of a GNIS stream ID. If no GNIS stream ID was present for a series of arcs, like NHD "Level" attributes were used to determine the network. The resulting routes represent what are commonly referred to as streams under the aforementioned guidelines. Streams are catalogued with a unique LLID identifier. Although derived from Latitude/Longitude coordinates, the LLID should be used as a stream identifier only and not as a spatial identifier.The combination of established streams (GNIS) and calculated stream levels (relating flow with spatial attributes) creates a stream layer more complete and compatible with fisheries applications. Stream based hydrography expands the options available for storing location information by reducing the number of records needed to describe a location event. As a result, CDFG/PSMFC as well as other users will benefit from the stream based hydrography in its efforts to maintain a large database of stream based data.Explanation of the addition of new linework into the hydrography and the exclusion of NHD linework from the hydrography can be found in the Data Quality section of this document.September 2003cdfg_100k_2003_6cdfg_100k_2003_6vector Once established, LLID of a stream does not change regardless of changes to stream network. LLID is not to be used as a location identifier.NAMENAMEString60Geographic Names Information System (GNIS from USGS) NameLENGTH_FTLENGTH_FTNumber19Length of stream network in feet5UPXUPXNumber195Teale-Albers X coordinate at headwater of streamUPYUPYNumber19Teale-Albers Y coordinate at headwater of stream5DOWNXDOWNXNumber195Teale-Albers X coordinate at mouth of streamDOWNYDOWNYNumber195Teale-Albers Y coordinate at mouth of streamDOWN_LLIDDOWN_LLIDString20LLID of stream directly downstream of stream.DOWN_NAMEDOWN_NAMEString60GNIS Name of stream directly downstream of stream.DOWN_MEASDOWN_MEASNumber192Measured location on downstream stream of mouth of streamMOUTHMOUTHString24Explanation of occurence on stream of no downstream LLID.98.13298.132WinZipwww.calfish.orgProgram Manager(530) 225-2052(530) 225-2267ehaney@dfg.ca.govEric HaneyCalifornia Department of Fish and GameDownloadable Data100,000online11/02/01publication dateNHDThe linework used in this shapefile is from the digitized 1:100,000 National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) freely distributed over the internet by the United States Geological Survey (USGS). Not all of the linework available for the coverage area was used in the development of the dataset. Only linework that represents valid stream networks in the opinion of the data technician was used to network streams. Other linework such as what was considered an outlying stream or an unroutable canal or pipeline network was not included. This linework is available for future consideration for inclusion into the dataset. Also, additional linework was digitized by the data technician to complete stream networks where digitized linework is not available from the NHD but stream delineation is present on USGS 1:24,000 or 1:100,000 quadrangles. New linework was digitized on screen (heads up) at a scale of 1:10,000 or larger. Record of CDFG added linework can be found in the bigroutes coverage arc feature attribute table, field Ftype, attribute DFG CONNECTOR.Metadata imported.D:\l_tchristy\route100k\2003_5\cdfg_100k_2003_5.shp.xml2003100913020900Metadata imported.D:\route100k\2003_5\cdfg_100k_2003_5.shp.xml2003102211125400Dataset copied.D:\route100k\2003_5_NAD83\cdfg_100k_2003_52003110510445000Metadata imported.D:\route100k\2003_5_junk\NAD83be114.shp.xml2003120210334900Microsoft Windows 2000 Version 5.0 (Build 2195) Service Pack 4; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.3.0.800cdfg_100k_2003_6-373491.063464565384.49899549165.763088-603462.5132431-124.557572-113.10767342.96353332.4189291ISO 19115 Geographic Information - MetadataDIS_ESRI1.0dataset002file://\\ISB-EHANEY\D$\aaa\a_Hydro\NAD83\cdfg_100k_2003_6.shpLocal Area Network98.132Shapefile6340320031202Custom
